description: Among the most popular – and most-maligned -- sub-genres of fiction are detective and mystery novels, with plots that gradually “reveal the concealed” and uncover answers to ancient questions: Who did it? Who committed the crime? Who is guilty, and why? In this course we analyze the long-term and growing appeal of this sub-genre in its historical, sociological, cultural and literary contexts. We cover the historical and critical development of detective fiction as it began to emerge in the mid-nineteenth century in America (Poe) and England (Conan Doyle and Wilkie Collins), to the development of the figure of the private detective ( Sherlock Holmes, Agatha Christie’s Poirot and Miss Marple, Dorothy Sayers’ Lord Peter Wimsey) in the Golden Age of detective fiction in Britain (whodunits and puzzlers). In America, the sub-genre detours into hardboiled and noir crime thrillers, fiction featuring female detectives, police procedurals, courtroom thrillers, “ethnic” detective series and the advent of the psychopathic serial killer. We will also make a few forays into international examples of the genre, in Continental, African and possibly Asian work. In investigating the narrative structures of detective fiction, we consider the significance of its various sources: the Gothic novel and penny dreadfuls/dimestore novels, among other sources. The course also introduces contemporary critical and theoretical arguments concerning popular fiction and genre studies, to enable advanced students to develop a sophisticated understanding of these texts and their cultural contexts, as well as examples of these texts in film and television series.
goals: Students will develop more sophisticated language skills to read widely and deeply in target language and employ these skills for cross-cultural understanding and improved communication
In engaging with literary and critical texts from different periods, students will have a deeper understanding of cultural, historical and literary contexts
In leading class discussions, presenting topics for seminar papers and drafting a research paper, students will develop greater professionalism as scholars of literature
